Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide travel funding and conference registration fees for US-based undergraduate and graduate students to attend the 2013 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) to be held in New Orleans, LA on December 9-13, 2013. ACSAC is a top-tier academic security conference that regularly brings together the foremost minds in academic, governmental and commercial computer security to both address the most pressing problems in applied computer security, as well discuss seminal works in information security. The broader impact will be to facilitate interaction, and to groom the next generation of security professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 29th Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) was held in New Orleans, LA on December 9-13, 2013. ACSAC is a top-tier academic security conference whose core mission is investigating practical solutions for computer security technology. Run by the Applied Computer Security Associates (ACSA), it brings together the foremost minds in academia, industry, and government to address the most pressing problems in applied computer security, as well as discuss seminal works in information security. The conference program is comprised of two days of tutorials and workshops, and three days of keynote talks, panels, a “works-in-progress” or WIP session, a poster session, and technical paper sessions. There were 228 attendees from 25 countries, with 198 attending the general conference, and 30 attending tutorials and workshops only. The technical sessions included 34 accepted papers out of 171 submissions, giving an acceptance rate of 19.8%. The papers were from across the world, including the United States, Canada, Germany, France, Switzerland, New Zealand, Greece, Israel, and Turkey.

ACSAC attracts many students – of the 228 attendees, 58 were students. A total of 17 students were supported through a combination of NSF and DHS funding and ACSAC funding from general registration fees. NSF and DHS funding was used exclusively to support US students. ACSAC funding supported US students as well as non-US students. Supported US students represented:

  • University of New Orleans
  • Florida Atlantic University
  • Florida International University
  • University of North Texas
  • University of Texas at Dallas
  • University of Puerto Rico
  • University of California, Santa Barbara
  • Virginia Commonwealth University
  • Arizona State University
  • Purdue University (2 students)

ACSAC supported non-US students from Greece, Israel, India, and Turkey. An additional 41 students attending the conference received discounted registration fees paid by ACSAC from general registration fees.

Of the 17 students who received support to attend ACSAC, 2 were pursuing Masters degrees, and 15 were in their PhD program. Many of the supported students had an active role in the conference: 9 had accepted papers, 3 presented in the WIP session, and 2 had posters in the poster session. Four of the students were women and 1 was an under-represented minority.

ACSAC supported the TracerFIRE training class, a forensic and incident response exercise program developed by Sandia and Los Alamos National Laboratories as part of its program. There were 18 participants in the TracerFIRE class, including 11 students. NSF and DHS funding provided registration fee waivers for 5 students and travel support for 4 of these students.

NSF and DHS funding provided honorariums, registration fees, and travel support for two keynote speakers, including the Invited Essayist, Dr. Carl Landwehr from the George Washington University who spoke on A Building Code for Building Code – Putting What We Know Works to Work, and the Distinguished Practitioner, Dr. Nancy Leveson of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who talked about Applying Systems Thinking to Security and Safety. NSF funding also provided honorariums, registration fees, and/or travel support for tutorial instructors.

A key goal of the ACSAC 2013 Student Support effort was to provide opportunities for student education, as well as training and professional development. Students participating in the conference gained valuable insight into current research. A number of students shared their research with other conference participants by presenting papers, WIPs, and/or posters.
